docs.snippet: The European Community showed signs today that it was preparing to modify a position on farm subsidies that has brought global trade liberalization talks here near collapse.   The community's Council of Ministers asked its Executive Commission to...
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Community showed signs today that it was preparing to modify a position on farm subsidies that has brought global trade liberalization talks here near collapse. The community's Council of Ministers asked its Executive Commission to reassess the situation in light of the community's isolation here on the farm issue. French and German ministers also announced that President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany would hold a hastily scheduled meeting on Wednesday in Paris.

headline.main: Europe Hints It May Ease Stance at Farm Trade Talks

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: World trade talks appeared to be just hours from collapse early this morning as negotiations reached a crisis over the European Community's continuing failure to agree to make larger cuts in agricultural subsidies.   After a late-night negotiating...
docs.lead_paragraph: World trade talks appeared to be just hours from collapse early this morning as negotiations reached a crisis over the European Community's continuing failure to agree to make larger cuts in agricultural subsidies. After a late-night negotiating session that began Wednesday ended in acrimony and accusations, numerous ministers said the talks would fall apart at noon today, a deadline set by the conference chairman, unless the community adopted a more flexible position on farm protection.

headline.main: Trade Talks Seem on the Verge of Collapse

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Another crisis erupted in the 107-nation trade talks late tonight, dashing hope that had been raised earlier in the day when both the United States and the European Community made concessions that allowed the deadlocked negotiations to continue. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: Another crisis erupted in the 107-nation trade talks late tonight, dashing hope that had been raised earlier in the day when both the United States and the European Community made concessions that allowed the deadlocked negotiations to continue. The talks are aimed at lowering barriers on the nearly $4 trillion of annual world trade. The latest crisis resulted from a continuing failure to resolve farm trade issues. The new trouble revived earlier fears of a conference collapse that could bring trade wars and a general worldwide economic decline. "It's back to ground zero," said John C. Crosbie, Canada's Trade Minister. 'Brutally Torpedoed' Australia's Minister for Trade Negotiations, Neal Blewett, said he had "never before been in a meeting in which there was a promise of getting a breakthrough and it was so brutally torpedoed."

headline.main: After Brief Hope, New Trade Snag

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: By refusing to budge on protectionist farm policies, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France have sabotaged the Uruguay Round of international trade talks. Yesterday the talks were suspended when third world food...
docs.lead_paragraph: By refusing to budge on protectionist farm policies, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France have sabotaged the Uruguay Round of international trade talks. Yesterday the talks were suspended when third world food exporting nations decided to pull out. President Mitterrand is known for grand rhetorical speeches on behalf of the world's poor nations. After this week in Brussels, the rhetoric rings hollow. The trade barriers Mr. Mitterrand is obstinately defending cost the third world two and a half times more than all the aid the industrialized nations dole out to them. Apparently, helping the poor of the world was not as high on his agenda as pan dering to a handful of wealthier domestic farmers.

docs.snippet: A four-year round of talks to establish new rules for world trade broke off in disarray today as the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked over the issue of reducing subsidies to farmers.   Trade ministers had set today as a...
docs.lead_paragraph: A four-year round of talks to establish new rules for world trade broke off in disarray today as the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked over the issue of reducing subsidies to farmers. Trade ministers had set today as a deadline to reach an agreement to liberalize rules governing $4 trillion in annual world trade. The goal was an accord that could increase economic growth and living standards worldwide by removing government rules that restrict trade not only in agriculture but also in a wide range of manufactured goods, financial services and technological expertise.

headline.main: TRADE TALKS END WITHOUT MENDING RIFT OVER FARMING

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: On the morning this week that President Bush awoke in Buenos Aires, a local newspaper carried a front-page cartoon showing a crowd of tall men in dark glasses surrounding an almost invisible Mr. Bush, protecting him from the slight figure of...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning this week that President Bush awoke in Buenos Aires, a local newspaper carried a front-page cartoon showing a crowd of tall men in dark glasses surrounding an almost invisible Mr. Bush, protecting him from the slight figure of President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina. The dialogue went this way: "Mr. President, there's a guy here who says he's the President of the natives. Has a Latin aspect, is between five and six feet tall and weighs about 130 pounds."

headline.main: Buenos Aires Journal; An Army Revolt One Day, an Invasion the Next

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Sometimes it was hard to hear President Bush's message on democracy, what with all the bombs, gunfire, prison breakouts and military rebellions exploding across Latin America this week.    "What are we doing here?" a White House official demanded...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes it was hard to hear President Bush's message on democracy, what with all the bombs, gunfire, prison breakouts and military rebellions exploding across Latin America this week. "What are we doing here?" a White House official demanded querulously of another when the Bush entourage reached Argentina on the heels of an army rebellion. "There were six bodies in the street outside here yesterday."

headline.main: Reporter's Notebook; Fidgety Bush Gets No Eggs On Latin Trip

byline.original: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: THIS is not the way it was supposed to work out.    Because of their industrial interests, the United States and the European Community were expected to be on the same side in the trade talks that broke down Friday. Instead, they were at each other's...
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is not the way it was supposed to work out. Because of their industrial interests, the United States and the European Community were expected to be on the same side in the trade talks that broke down Friday. Instead, they were at each other's throats.

headline.main: Headliners; Europe's Farmers Plow a Trade Treaty Under

docs.snippet: If the European Community does not eventually compromise on the farm trade issue that caused the collapse of the international trade talks here last week, there could be a painful return to the kind of trade warfare that aggravated the economic...
docs.lead_paragraph: If the European Community does not eventually compromise on the farm trade issue that caused the collapse of the international trade talks here last week, there could be a painful return to the kind of trade warfare that aggravated the economic crises of the 1930's. Some officials still hold out hopes that the liberalization effort can be salvaged early next year when governments cool off and take a new look at the impasse over farm subsidies.

headline.main: Planting a Seed for Trade Wars

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The collapse of global trade talks in Brussels last week in a dispute over farm subsidies does not mean the negotiators are finished.    Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter will visit the European Community's Commissioner for Agriculture, Ray...
docs.lead_paragraph: The collapse of global trade talks in Brussels last week in a dispute over farm subsidies does not mean the negotiators are finished. Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter will visit the European Community's Commissioner for Agriculture, Ray MacSharry of Ireland, on Friday, at Mr. MacSharry's invitation. Mr. Yeutter, who owns a big ranch in Nebraska, and Mr. MacSharry, a former cattle salesman, were the main adversaries at last week's Brussels meeting, which was held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade.

headline.main: Trade Talks Will Continue in Informal Settings

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times
